titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Teunis D. Huntting genealogical records of Long Island families 1980.005
titlestmt.author: John Zarrillo
titlestmt.sponsor: Revised and expanded description of this collection was made possible thanks to the generosity of The Robert David Lion Gardiner Foundation.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2025-03-24 19:22:45 +0000.
profiledesc.langusage: Description is written in: English, Latin script.

did.unittitle: Teunis D. Huntting genealogical records of Long Island families
did.abstract: This collection contains Teunis G. Huntting's notes on the genealogy of Long Island families, with information copied from church records in East Hampton, Long Island. The volume was assembled circa 1880 to 1900, and the genealogical information included is centered upon the 18th and 19th centuries.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Immediate source of acquisition unknown. Accessioned in 1980.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection consists of a single volume, with the information arranged by family.

bioghist.head: Biographical note
bioghist.p: Teunis Dimon Huntting was born on September 22, 1848 in East Hampton,Long Island, NY to James Madison Huntting (1812-1868) and Mary Esther Dimon (1820-1898). He married Georgia Weed Hammond in 1871 and they had three children. He died on June 2, 1926 in Brooklyn, NY.

Huntting was a dedicated genealogist. He wrote: "The Hunting, Or Huntting Family In America" (1888), "Heinrick family" (undated), "Descendants of Abraham Huntting: the sixth in line from John Huntting, the first of the name in America" (1910), and "Genealogy of the Mulford family through the line of William the ancestor and Thomas J. of the eighth generation" (1900). All of these are available to be read at the Center for Brooklyn History.

list.head: Source:
list.item: "Teunis Dimon Huntting." Long Island Surnames. Accessed March 24, 2025. https://longislandsurnames.com/getperson.php?personID=I04135&tree=ConklinAnanias

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item, date (if known); Teunis D. Huntting genealogical records of Long Island families, 1980.005, Box and Folder number; Brooklyn Public Library, Center for Brooklyn History.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This finding aid was revised by Dee Bowers in 2025. Portions of the revised description were written by Cecilia Wright as part of a project to assess and improve access to archival collections in CBH's holdings that relate to Long Island, made possible thanks to the generosity of The Robert David Lion Gardiner Foundation.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Additional genealogies and family papers can be found by searching our library catalog.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Writings by Teunis D. Huntting at CBH:
The Hunting, or Huntting family in America, 1888. CS71.H8688 1888
Descendants of Abraham Huntting : the sixth in line from John Huntting, the first of the name in America, 1910. CS71.H8688 1910
Associators of the town of East Hampton, N.Y., April 1775, 1900. F127.L853 L66 1900z v. 2
Genealogy of the Mulford family through the line of William the ancestor and Thomas J. of the eighth generation, 1900. CS71.M854 1900
A digitized version of one of Huntting's journals containing genealogical information is available online: https://www.heirloomsreunited.com/2017/06/c1870s1880s-journal-with-genealogy-of.html

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection contains Teunis G. Huntting's notes on the genealogy of Long Island families, with information copied from church records in East Hampton, Long Island. The volume was assembled circa 1880 to 1900, and the genealogical information included is centered upon the 18th and 19th centuries. The information contained within this volume includes first name, last name, baptismal date, date of marriage, the name of spouse, and date of death, with the cell left blank when the information is not available.

This work is broken up by family, and includes information on the following families: Baker, Barns, Conklin, Darbe, Dayton, Dimon, Edwards, Filer, Fithian, Hand, Hedges, Hicks, Hopping, Huntting, Jones, Miller, Mulford, Murdock, Osborn, Paine, Parsons, Schellinger, Sherrill, Stratton, and Talmage.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The materials in this collection are in the public domain.

While many items at the Center for Brooklyn History are unrestricted, we do not own reproduction rights to all materials. Be aware of the several kinds of rights that might apply: copyright, licensing and trademarks. The researcher assumes all responsibility for copyright questions.
